div.div: ἀῡτή : loud, far-reaching call, cry; ὥς τε με κουρά̄ων ἀμφήλυθε θῆλυς ἀῡτή (the outcry of the maidens, when the ball with which they were playing fell into the river, had awakened Odysseus), Od. 6.122; esp. the battle-cry, and so, suggestively, for battle itself, δεινῆς ἀκόρητοι ἀῡτῆς, Il. 13.621; μεμαυἶ ἔριδος καὶ ἀῡτῆς, Il. 5.732; ὀψείοντες ἀῡτῆς καὶ πολέμοιο, Il. 14.37.
From A Homeric Dictionary (Georg Autenrieth, New York, Harper and Brothers, 1891)
